1.title: Info
1.content: A card is a visually appealing element used to present short or compact pieces of information. It is visualized as a container which groups various pieces of content that acts as entry point to detailed information. It displays content and actions on a single topic.

inputs: Keep it simple – cards should contain only required element to create focused view, don’t undercut this focus by adding complexity into you card.
Keep it consistent – use similar structure for all cards in the same group / of the same kind.

3.title: Overview
3.content: Buttons are clickable elements that are used to trigger actions. They communicate calls to action to the user and allow users to interact with pages in a variety of ways. Button labels express what action will occur when the user interacts with it.

4.title: Fluid versus default buttons
4.content: Button alignment is also closely related to whether the button is treated as a default or a fluid element within a layout. When we say âfluidâ, we mean that the button becomes a part of a larger, compound component by bleeding to two or more edges of its container. Rather than defining the a fluid buttonâs width in columns or mini units, its width is defined as a percentage (often 50%) of the containerâs width. Also, as a general rule, fluid primary buttons are never left-aligned in a layout or a containerâtheyâre always either right-aligned, or span the full width of the container.

content.text1: Use buttons to communicate actions users can take and to allow users to interact with the page. Each page should have only one primary button, and any remaining calls to action should be represented as lower emphasis buttons.
content.text2: Do not use buttons as navigational elements. Instead, use links when the desired action is to take the user to a new page.
